Young Researchers’ Bootcamp on Machine Learning for Materials Science and Quantum Simulation

Join us for a fully funded eight-week bootcamp on developing and applying cutting-edge machine-learning tools to pressing problems in materials science and quantum simulation

Find Out More

MATERIAL SCIENCE BOOTCAMP

By developing new, complex representations of data, machine learning has led to powerful modelling approaches in many scientific disciplines. The introduction of these methods to materials science is still recent, and many published applications do not take full advantage of the strengths of machine learning techniques and therefore do not replicate the successes they have had in other fields. The opportunity, however, is enormous: being able to more accurately and more quickly predict the properties of materials would allow promising new catalysts, solar cells, or batteries to be designed computationally, reducing the time and expense of trial and error experimentation in the lab. To take advantage of this opportunity, this targeted Bootcamp will bring together early career researchers to develop new machine learning techniques and apply them to important problems in materials science and quantum simulation.

ABOUT


We will fund up to three participants in each of the three themes, listed below, that sit at the intersection of materials simulation and machine learning. The Bootcamp will strengthen interdisciplinary collaboration via hands on projects that will define the benefits and limitations of machine learning, introduce exciting open problems to the broader community, and stimulate new approaches to solving challenging open problems.


The Bootcamp will take place at the University of Sydney, with its uniquely relevant world-class research initiatives and institutes. The Bootcamp is organised by the Computational Materials Design Grand Challenge project of the Sydney Nano Institute, but will also draw on the expertise of researchers in the Faculty of Science, Centre for Translational Data Science (CTDS) and the Sydney Mathematical Research Institute (SMRI) . In addition, social activities are planned to help you make friends and take advantage of your stay in Australia and its beautiful environment.



Participants will spend 8 weeks as part of diverse, collaborative research teams, from the kick-off on 15 July until 15 September. While we prefer participants to take part in the entire Bootcamp, we can accommodate some flexibility in start and end dates.


Participants will not enter into an employment relationship with the University of Sydney, but will have their expenses either covered upfront or reimbursed. Expenses eligible for reimbursement include airfare and other transport, visa costs, accommodation, meals, and childcare.





Please direct any inquiries to Dr Lamiae Azizi and Prof Ivan Kassal.


PROJECTS

Machine learning for better carbon dioxide hydrogenation catalysts

There is little question that the sustainable reductive transformation of CO2 is one of the most important scientific and technical challenges of the 21st century. Machine learning methods have proven successful in the prediction of a large number of material properties. However, there is still a number of challenges in computational material sciences and there is a need for novel strategies to overcome them. Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation is one of the most important prototype reactions in heterogeneous catalysis, and the current big challenge is the lack of low cost, highly selective, active and stable catalysts to synthesize valuable C2 chemicals. This theme will assess the performance of existing methods for predicting the performance of carbon dioxide hydrogenation catalysts, and develop new ideas to accelerate the engineering and design of complex materials with improved functionalities.

Principal Investigators: Prof. Catherine Stampfl, Dr Lamiae Azizi

Machine learning force fields for better solar cells

Solar cells incorporating perovskite materials are the fastest advancing solar technology to date, with the potential to be rapidly manufactured via energy efficient printing processes. Scaling up their printing, however, requires detailed understanding of how thin films of solid perovskites form from soluble precursors, including the effect of parameters such as temperature, solvent and additives. This project will develop force fields that can be used to simulate the steps involved in the formation of metal halide perovskites from solution. Recently, machine-learning has been used to construct force fields for a range of applications in material sciences, but they usually require tuning by hand and cannot be deployed at scale. We will overcome these limitations to develop general-purpose ap-proaches for this important class of materials.

Principal Investigators: Dr Asaph-Widmer Cooper, Dr Lamiae Azizi

Machine learning for the quantum control of an experimental quantum simulator

Quantum computing is the latest frontier in materials science, promising simulations that are exponentially faster than possible on conventional computers. At USyd, we are developing a state of the art trapped ion quantum computer that will be able to simulate, with existing technology, the otherwise intractable quantum-mechanical equations that describe processes in chemistry and materials science. However, like all quantum computers, the performance of our device is adversely impacted by noise or fluctuations in its environment. This project will design control protocols to be optimised over the enormous space of experimentally controllable parameters to improve our computations and their resilience to noise.

Principal Investigators: Dr Cornelius Hempel, Dr Lamiae Azizi, A/Prof Ivan Kassal

APPLY


We are looking for early career researchers, whether computer scientists, mathematicians, or physical scientists who are experts in machine learning and are interested in developing and applying machine learning techniques to one of the three projects above. We particularly encourage applications from final year PhD students and recent PhD graduates, from anywhere in the world.

We celebrate diversity and are committed to creating an inclusive environment for all our teammates. We especially encourage applications from women, Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, as well as members of ethnic or cultural minorities or other groups underrepresented in computational and physical sciences.


Application deadline: 15 March 2020.

Outcomes will be announced by 31 March.
